value.title: Best Practice for Power BI Workspace Roles Setup
value.excerpt: Power BI workspaces are not like old days, that we had Edit access and View access anymore. You have more options for roles in a workspace, and in my courses, I have found that many people choose the incorrect role without knowing what the role does. In this video, I'll explain all the roles in the workspace,
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/I7om73MQ3q8" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: CDS and CDM are Not the Same   Difference Explained
value.excerpt: Working with Power BI and Power Platform dataflows, or using Dynamics in general, might cause you to hear one of these two CDS (Common Data Services), or CDM (Common Data Model). Often there is a misconception about these two, and many people think they are the same. In this video, I’ll explain the difference
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uEPx1utIzc8" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Combining Tables in Power BI   Union Except and Intersect in DAX
value.excerpt: Power Query is often the engine used for combining data tables, especially using Merge or Append. However, sometimes, you might need to do that operation in DAX. An example of that is when you want to create that combination only virtually as part of a measure calculation that evaluates dynamically.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IPziqmQgJFw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX Measure in the Axis of the Power BI Report
value.excerpt: If you even need to show your DAX measures in a chart without a dimension to slice and dice it, you won’t get a great experience in the visual. In this video, I’ll share a trick that you can use to have a nice visualization like what you see in the above screenshot. Download the file and study more from
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CRs2CnW7tVU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Fibonacci Sequence   Understanding the Power Query Recursive Function for Power BI
value.excerpt: Recursive functions in Power Query are not very popular, but sometimes very helpful when in need. In this post, I'll explain what a recursive function is, how it works, and explain it through a famous recursive example of Fibonacci Sequence. Download the code, and Power BI file from my blog article here:

value.title: Get the Day of the Week Name and Number in Power BI Using DAX

value.title: How to Use Time and Date Dimensions in a Power BI Model

value.title: One Dimension Filters Another Dimension in Power BI
value.excerpt: I often get this question after I explain about the star-schema. The question is that both my dimensions are filtering my fact table values, but how can I get one dimension filtering another dimension? for example, how can I get only the list of products that have been purchased by this customer? In

value.title: Power BI DAX Back to Basics   Scalar Vs Tabular Functions
value.excerpt: DAX is the analytical language in Power BI. Learning this language, however, comes with some difficulties. Part of that challenge is the way that functions work in DAX. Learning the output of functions is an important element of learning how and where you can use them. In this video, I'll explain two
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MI7WIwBFhU0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Power BI Desktop Download or Microsoft Store App   Which One is better
value.excerpt: If you want to develop Power BI reports, you'll need the Power BI Desktop application. However, Power BI Desktop application comes in two ways; Download it separately and install it on your Windows machine, or Get it from Microsoft Store as an App. The question that I often get is; What is the difference?
